</tbody></table><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1289143401">@media(max-width:640px){body:not(.skin-minerva) .mw-parser-output .infobox{width:100%!important}body:not(.skin-minerva) .mw-parser-output .infobox th{width:50%}}@media screen{html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota tr{background:transparent!important}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota img{background:transparent}}@media screen and (prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota tr{background:transparent!important}html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota img{background:white}}.mw-parser-output .infobox.biota .taxobox-edit-taxonomy img{background:transparent!important}body.skin-vector .mw-parser-output table.biota.infobox{margin-top:0.5em}body.skin--responsive .mw-parser-output table.biota.infobox tr.taxonrow2 td{padding:2px 10px}</style>
<p>The <b>dog</b> (<i><b>Canis familiaris</b></i> or <i><b>Canis lupus familiaris</b></i>) is a <a href="/wiki/Domestication_of_vertebrates" title="Domestication of vertebrates">domesticated</a> descendant of the <a href="/wiki/Gray_wolf" class="mw-redirect" title="Gray wolf">gray wolf</a>. Also called the <b>domestic dog</b>, it was <a href="/wiki/Selective_breeding" title="Selective breeding">selectively bred</a> from a population of wolves during the <a href="/wiki/Late_Pleistocene" title="Late Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a> by <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherers</a>. The dog was the first <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a> to be domesticated by <a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">humans</a>, over 14,000 years ago and before the <a href="/wiki/History_of_agriculture" title="History of agriculture">development of agriculture</a>. Due to their long association with humans, dogs have gained the ability to thrive on a <a href="/wiki/Starch" title="Starch">starch</a>-rich diet that would be inadequate for other <a href="/wiki/Canidae" title="Canidae">canids</a>.
</p><p>Dogs have been bred for desired behaviors, sensory capabilities, and physical attributes. <a href="/wiki/Dog_breed" title="Dog breed">Dog breeds</a> vary widely in shape, size, and color. They have the same number of bones (with the exception of the tail), powerful jaws that house around 42 teeth, and well-developed <a href="/wiki/Dog_sense_of_smell" title="Dog sense of smell">senses of smell</a>, hearing, and sight. Compared to humans, dogs possess a superior sense of smell and hearing, but inferior <a href="/wiki/Visual_acuity" title="Visual acuity">visual acuity</a>. Dogs perform many roles for humans, such as <a href="/wiki/Hunting_dog" title="Hunting dog">hunting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herding_dog" title="Herding dog">herding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sled_dog" title="Sled dog">pulling loads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guard_dog" title="Guard dog">protection</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pet" title="Pet">companionship</a>, <a href="/wiki/Therapy_dog" title="Therapy dog">therapy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Service_dog" class="mw-redirect" title="Service dog">aiding disabled people</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Police_dog" title="Police dog">assisting police</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Dogs_in_warfare" title="Dogs in warfare">military</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Dog_communication" title="Dog communication">Communication in dogs</a> includes eye gaze, facial expression, vocalization, body posture (including movements of bodies and limbs), and gustatory communication (scents, pheromones, and taste). They mark their territories by urinating on them, which is more likely when entering a new environment. Over the millennia, dogs have uniquely adapted to human behavior; this adaptation includes being able to understand and communicate with humans. As such, the <a href="/wiki/Human%E2%80%93canine_bond" title="Humancanine bond">humancanine bond</a> has been a topic of frequent study, and dogs' influence on human society has given them the <a href="/wiki/Sobriquet" title="Sobriquet">sobriquet</a> of "<a href="/wiki/Man%27s_best_friend" title="Man's best friend">man's best friend</a>".
</p><p>The global dog population is estimated at 700 million to 1 billion, <a href="/wiki/Cosmopolitan_distribution" title="Cosmopolitan distribution">distributed around the world</a>. The dog is the most popular pet in the United States, present in 3440% of households. Developed countries make up approximately 20% of the global dog population, while around 75% of dogs are estimated to be from developing countries, mainly in the form of feral and community dogs.
</p>

<p><a href="/wiki/African_wild_dog" title="African wild dog">African wild dog</a> <span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Dogs,_jackals,_wolves,_and_foxes_(Plate_XLIV).png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Dogs%2C_jackals%2C_wolves%2C_and_foxes_%28Plate_XLIV%29.png/60px-Dogs%2C_jackals%2C_wolves%2C_and_foxes_%28Plate_XLIV%29.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="31" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Dogs%2C_jackals%2C_wolves%2C_and_foxes_%28Plate_XLIV%29.png/120px-Dogs%2C_jackals%2C_wolves%2C_and_foxes_%28Plate_XLIV%29.png 1.5x" data-file-width="445" data-file-height="277"></a></span>
</p>
</td></tr>

<tr>
<td style="text-align: left; font-size: 88%; border: 0; padding: 0;">Cladogram and divergence of the gray wolf (including the domestic dog) among its closest extant relatives<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Dogs are domesticated members of the family <a href="/wiki/Canidae" title="Canidae">Canidae</a>. They are classified as a <a href="/wiki/Subspecies_of_Canis_lupus" title="Subspecies of Canis lupus">subspecies of <i>Canis lupus</i></a>, along with <a href="/wiki/Wolves" class="mw-redirect" title="Wolves">wolves</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dingoes" class="mw-redirect" title="Dingoes">dingoes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Thiele-2019_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thiele-2019-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs were domesticated from wolves over 14,000 years ago by <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherers</a>, before the development of agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The remains of the <a href="/wiki/Bonn%E2%80%93Oberkassel_dog" title="BonnOberkassel dog">BonnOberkassel dog</a>, buried alongside humans between 14,000 and 15,000 years ago, are the earliest to be conclusively identified as a domesticated dog.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:7_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Genetic studies show that dogs likely diverged from wolves between 27,000 and 40,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The dingo and the related <a href="/wiki/New_Guinea_singing_dog" title="New Guinea singing dog">New Guinea singing dog</a> resulted from the <a href="/wiki/Geographic_isolation" class="mw-redirect" title="Geographic isolation">geographic isolation</a> and feralization of dogs in <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a> over 8,000 years ago.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Dogs, wolves, and <a href="/wiki/Dingo" title="Dingo">dingoes</a> have sometimes been classified as separate species.<sup id="cite_ref-Thiele-2019_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thiele-2019-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 1758, the Swedish botanist and zoologist <a href="/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus" title="Carl Linnaeus">Carl Linnaeus</a> assigned the <a href="/wiki/Genus" title="Genus">genus</a> name <i><a href="/wiki/Canis" title="Canis">Canis</a></i> (which is the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> word for "dog")<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWangTedford200858_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWangTedford200858-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> to the domestic dog, the <a href="/wiki/Wolf" title="Wolf">wolf</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Golden_jackal" title="Golden jackal">golden jackal</a> in his book, <i><a href="/wiki/10th_edition_of_Systema_Naturae" title="10th edition of Systema Naturae">Systema Naturae</a></i>. He classified the domestic dog as <i>Canis familiaris</i> and, on the next page, classified the grey wolf as <i>Canis lupus</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-linnaeus1758_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-linnaeus1758-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Linnaeus considered the dog to be a separate species from the wolf because of its upturning tail (<i>cauda recurvata</i> in <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> term), which is not found in any other <a href="/wiki/Canid" class="mw-redirect" title="Canid">canid</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Clutton-Brock1995_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Clutton-Brock1995-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the 2005 edition of <i><a href="/wiki/Mammal_Species_of_the_World" title="Mammal Species of the World">Mammal Species of the World</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Mammalogist" class="mw-redirect" title="Mammalogist">mammalogist</a> <a href="/wiki/W._Christopher_Wozencraft" class="mw-redirect" title="W. Christopher Wozencraft">W. Christopher Wozencraft</a> listed the wolf as a wild subspecies of <i>Canis lupus</i> and proposed two additional subspecies: <i>familiaris</i>, as named by Linnaeus in 1758, and <i>dingo</i>, named by Meyer in 1793. Wozencraft included <i>hallstromi</i> (the New Guinea singing dog) as another name (<a href="/wiki/Junior_synonym" class="mw-redirect" title="Junior synonym">junior synonym</a>) for the dingo. This classification was informed by a 1999 <a href="/wiki/Mitochondrial_DNA" title="Mitochondrial DNA">mitochondrial DNA</a> study.<sup id="cite_ref-wozencraft2005_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wozencraft2005-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The classification of dingoes is disputed and a political issue in Australia. Classifying dingoes as wild dogs simplifies reducing or controlling dingo populations that threaten livestock. Treating dingoes as a separate species allows conservation programs to protect the dingo population.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dingo classification affects wildlife management policies, legislation, and societal attitudes.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2019, a workshop hosted by the <a href="/wiki/IUCN" class="mw-redirect" title="IUCN">IUCN</a>/Species Survival Commission's Canid Specialist Group considered the dingo and the New Guinea singing dog to be <a href="/wiki/Feral_dog" class="mw-redirect" title="Feral dog">feral</a> <i>Canis familiaris</i>. Therefore, it did not assess them for the <a href="/wiki/IUCN_Red_List" title="IUCN Red List">IUCN Red List</a> of <a href="/wiki/Threatened_species" title="Threatened species">threatened species</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Alvares2019_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alvares2019-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Domestication">Domestication</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Domestication_of_the_dog" title="Domestication of the dog">Domestication of the dog</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Comparison_of_a_wolf_and_a_pug.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Comparison_of_a_wolf_and_a_pug.png/250px-Comparison_of_a_wolf_and_a_pug.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="200" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Comparison_of_a_wolf_and_a_pug.png/500px-Comparison_of_a_wolf_and_a_pug.png 1.5x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="2400"></a><figcaption>Wolves (left) were domesticated by humans into dogs (right)</figcaption></figure>
<p>The earliest remains generally accepted to be those of a domesticated dog were discovered in <a href="/wiki/Oberkassel,_Bonn" title="Oberkassel, Bonn">Bonn-Oberkassel</a>, Germany. <a href="/wiki/Contextualism" title="Contextualism">Contextual</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isotope_analysis" title="Isotope analysis">isotopic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genetics" title="Genetics">genetic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Morphology_(biology)" title="Morphology (biology)">morphological</a> evidence shows that this dog was not a local wolf.<sup id="cite_ref-Perri2021_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Perri2021-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The dog was dated to 14,223 years ago and was found buried along with a man and a woman, all three having been sprayed with red <a href="/wiki/Hematite" title="Hematite">hematite</a> powder and buried under large, thick basalt blocks. The dog had died of <a href="/wiki/Canine_distemper" title="Canine distemper">canine distemper</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-janssens2018_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-janssens2018-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This timing indicates that the dog was the <a href="/wiki/Domestication_of_vertebrates" title="Domestication of vertebrates">first species to be domesticated</a><sup id="cite_ref-larson2014_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-larson2014-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-freedman2017_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedman2017-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> in the time of <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherers</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Frantz2020_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frantz2020-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which predates agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-Thalmann2018_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thalmann2018-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Earlier remains dating back to 30,000 years ago have been described as <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic_dog" title="Paleolithic dog">Paleolithic dogs</a>, but their status as dogs or wolves remains debated<sup id="cite_ref-Irving-Pease2018_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Irving-Pease2018-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> because considerable morphological diversity existed among wolves during the <a href="/wiki/Late_Pleistocene" title="Late Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Thalmann2018_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Thalmann2018-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/DNA_sequences" class="mw-redirect" title="DNA sequences">DNA sequences</a> show that all ancient and modern dogs share a common ancestry and descended from an ancient, extinct wolf population that was distinct from any <a href="/wiki/Wolf" title="Wolf">modern wolf</a> lineage. Some studies have posited that all living wolves are more closely related to each other than to dogs,<sup id="cite_ref-Bergstrm2020_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bergstrm2020-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Frantz2020_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frantz2020-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while others have suggested that dogs are more closely related to modern Eurasian wolves than to American wolves.<sup id="cite_ref-:43_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:43-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The dog is a domestic animal that likely travelled a <a href="/wiki/Commensalism" title="Commensalism">commensal</a> pathway into domestication (i.e. humans initially neither benefitted nor were harmed by wild dogs eating refuse from their camps).<sup id="cite_ref-Irving-Pease2018_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Irving-Pease2018-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-larson2012_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-larson2012-27"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The questions of when and where dogs were first domesticated remains uncertain.<sup id="cite_ref-larson2014_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-larson2014-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Genetic studies suggest a domestication process commencing over 25,000 years ago, in one or several wolf populations in either Europe, the high Arctic, or eastern Asia.<sup id="cite_ref-Ostrander2019_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ostrander2019-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2021, a <a href="/wiki/Literature_review" title="Literature review">literature review</a> of the current evidence <a href="/wiki/Inference" title="Inference">infers</a> that the dog was domesticated in <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a> 23,000 years ago by <a href="/wiki/Ancient_North_Siberians" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient North Siberians">ancient North Siberians</a>, then later dispersed eastward into the Americas and westward across Eurasia,<sup id="cite_ref-Perri2021_19-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Perri2021-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with dogs likely accompanying the first humans to inhabit the Americas.<sup id="cite_ref-Perri2021_19-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Perri2021-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some studies have suggested that the extinct <a href="/wiki/Japanese_wolf" title="Japanese wolf">Japanese wolf</a> is closely related to the ancestor of domestic dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-:43_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:43-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018, a study identified 429 genes that differed between modern dogs and modern wolves. As the differences in these genes could also be found in ancient dog fossils, these were regarded as being the result of the initial domestication and not from recent breed formation. These genes are linked to <a href="/wiki/Neural_crest" title="Neural crest">neural crest</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_nervous_system" title="Central nervous system">central nervous system</a> development. These genes affect <a href="/wiki/Embryogenesis" class="mw-redirect" title="Embryogenesis">embryogenesis</a> and can confer tameness, smaller jaws, floppy ears, and diminished craniofacial development, which distinguish domesticated dogs from wolves and are considered to reflect domestication syndrome. The study concluded that during early dog domestication, the initial selection was for behavior. This trait is influenced by those genes which act in the neural crest, which led to the phenotypes observed in modern dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Breeds">Breeds</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_breed" title="Dog breed">Dog breed</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Dog_type" title="Dog type">Dog type</a></div><p> There are around 450 official <a href="/wiki/Dog_breeds" class="mw-redirect" title="Dog breeds">dog breeds</a>, the most of any mammal.<sup id="cite_ref-Ostrander2019_28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ostrander2019-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs began diversifying in the <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian era</a>, when humans took control of their natural selection.<sup id="cite_ref-freedman2017_22-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedman2017-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Most breeds were derived from small numbers of founders within the last 200 years.<sup id="cite_ref-freedman2017_22-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedman2017-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Ostrander2019_28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ostrander2019-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Since then, dogs have undergone rapid <a href="/wiki/Phenotypic_plasticity" title="Phenotypic plasticity">phenotypic change</a> and have been subjected to <a href="/wiki/Artificial_selection" class="mw-redirect" title="Artificial selection">artificial selection</a> by humans. The skull, body, and limb proportions between breeds display more phenotypic diversity than can be found within the entire order of <a href="/wiki/Carnivore" title="Carnivore">carnivores</a>. These breeds possess distinct traits related to morphology, which include body size, skull shape, tail phenotype, fur type, and colour.<sup id="cite_ref-freedman2017_22-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedman2017-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As such, humans have long used dogs for their desirable traits to complete or fulfill a certain work or role. Their behavioural traits include guarding, herding, hunting,<sup id="cite_ref-freedman2017_22-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedman2017-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> retrieving, and scent detection. Their personality traits include hypersocial behavior, boldness, and aggression.<sup id="cite_ref-freedman2017_22-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedman2017-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Present-day dogs are dispersed around the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Ostrander2019_28-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ostrander2019-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An example of this dispersal is the numerous modern breeds of European lineage during the Victorian era.<sup id="cite_ref-Frantz2020_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Frantz2020-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><ul class="center gallery mw-gallery-nolines">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 240px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 235px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Dog_morphological_variation.png" class="mw-file-description" title="Morphological variation in six dogs"><img alt="Morphological variation in six dogs" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Dog_morphological_variation.png/250px-Dog_morphological_variation.png" decoding="async" width="221" height="170" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Dog_morphological_variation.png/500px-Dog_morphological_variation.png 1.5x" data-file-width="997" data-file-height="768"></a></span></div>
			<div class="gallerytext"><a href="/wiki/Morphology_(biology)" title="Morphology (biology)">Morphological variation</a> in six dogs</div>
		</li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 240px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 235px;"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Dog_coat_variation.png" class="mw-file-description" title="Phenotypic variation in four dogs"><img alt="Phenotypic variation in four dogs" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Dog_coat_variation.png/250px-Dog_coat_variation.png" decoding="async" width="162" height="170" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Dog_coat_variation.png/330px-Dog_coat_variation.png 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="805"></a></span></div>
			<div class="gallerytext"><a href="/wiki/Phenotype" title="Phenotype">Phenotypic variation</a> in four dogs</div>
		</li>
</ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Anatomy_and_physiology">Anatomy and physiology</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_anatomy" title="Dog anatomy">Dog anatomy</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Size_and_skeleton">Size and skeleton</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Dog_anatomy_lateral_skeleton_view_(full).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Dog_anatomy_lateral_skeleton_view_%28full%29.jpg/330px-Dog_anatomy_lateral_skeleton_view_%28full%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="256" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Dog_anatomy_lateral_skeleton_view_%28full%29.jpg/500px-Dog_anatomy_lateral_skeleton_view_%28full%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Dog_anatomy_lateral_skeleton_view_%28full%29.jpg/960px-Dog_anatomy_lateral_skeleton_view_%28full%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3451" data-file-height="2850"></a><figcaption>A lateral view of a dog skeleton</figcaption></figure>
<p>Dogs are extremely variable in size, ranging from one of the largest breeds, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Dane" title="Great Dane">Great Dane</a>, at 50 to 79 kg (110 to 174 lb) and 71 to 81 cm (28 to 32 in), to one of the smallest, the <a href="/wiki/Chihuahua_(dog)" class="mw-redirect" title="Chihuahua (dog)">Chihuahua</a>, at 0.5 to 3 kg (1.1 to 6.6 lb) and 13 to 20 cm (5.1 to 7.9 in).<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> All healthy dogs, regardless of their size and type, have the same number of bones (with the exception of the tail), although there is significant skeletal variation between dogs of different types.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe200412_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe200412-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The dog's skeleton is well adapted for running; the <a href="/wiki/Vertebra" title="Vertebra">vertebrae</a> on the neck and back have extensions for back muscles, consisting of <a href="/wiki/Epaxial_and_hypaxial_muscles" title="Epaxial and hypaxial muscles">epaxial muscles and hypaxial muscles</a>, to connect to; the long ribs provide room for the <a href="/wiki/Heart" title="Heart">heart</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lung" title="Lung">lungs</a>; and the shoulders are unattached to the skeleton, allowing for flexibility.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe200412_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe200412-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Compared to the dog's wolf-like ancestors, selective breeding since domestication has seen the dog's skeleton increase in size for larger types such as <a href="/wiki/Mastiff" title="Mastiff">mastiffs</a> and miniaturised for smaller types such as <a href="/wiki/Terrier" title="Terrier">terriers</a>; <a href="/wiki/Dwarfism" title="Dwarfism">dwarfism</a> has been selectively bred for some types where short legs are preferred, such as <a href="/wiki/Dachshund" title="Dachshund">dachshunds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corgi" class="mw-redirect" title="Corgi">corgis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Most dogs naturally have 26 vertebrae in their tails, but some with <a href="/wiki/Natural_bobtail" title="Natural bobtail">naturally short tails</a> have as few as three.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe200412_33-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe200412-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Selected_skulls.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Selected_skulls.jpg/250px-Selected_skulls.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="60" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Selected_skulls.jpg/500px-Selected_skulls.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5000" data-file-height="1200"></a><figcaption>Skulls of different breeds, from left to right: Pug; Boxer; Rottweiler; Wolf; Collie; Standard Poodle.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The dog's skull has identical components regardless of breed type, but there is significant <a href="/wiki/Cephalic_index" title="Cephalic index">divergence in terms of skull shape</a> between types.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839_34-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesHamilton197127_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesHamilton197127-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The three basic skull shapes are the elongated dolichocephalic type as seen in <a href="/wiki/Sighthound" title="Sighthound">sighthounds</a>, the intermediate mesocephalic or mesaticephalic type, and the very short and broad brachycephalic type exemplified by mastiff type skulls.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839_34-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFogle20093839-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesHamilton197127_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesHamilton197127-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The jaw contains around 42 teeth, and it has evolved for the consumption of flesh. Dogs use their <a href="/wiki/Carnassial_teeth" class="mw-redirect" title="Carnassial teeth">carnassial teeth</a> to cut food into bite-sized chunks, more especially meat.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Senses">Senses</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Dog_anatomy#Senses" title="Dog anatomy">Dog anatomy  Senses</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Vision_comparison_with_dogs.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Vision_comparison_with_dogs.jpg/250px-Vision_comparison_with_dogs.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="182" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Vision_comparison_with_dogs.jpg/500px-Vision_comparison_with_dogs.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5482" data-file-height="3993"></a><figcaption>The left half of the image shows the estimated difference in a dog's vision.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Dogs' senses include vision, hearing, smell, taste, touch, and <a href="/wiki/Magnetoreception" title="Magnetoreception">magnetoreception</a>. One study suggests that dogs can feel small variations in <a href="/wiki/Earth%27s_magnetic_field" title="Earth's magnetic field">Earth's magnetic field</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs prefer to defecate with their spines aligned in a northsouth position in calm <a href="/wiki/Magnetic_field" title="Magnetic field">magnetic field</a> conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Dogs' vision is <a href="/wiki/Dichromacy" title="Dichromacy">dichromatic</a>; their visual world consists of yellows, blues, and grays.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> They have difficulty differentiating between red and green,<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and much like other mammals, the dog's eye is composed of two types of cone cells compared to the human's three. The divergence of the eye axis of dogs ranges from 12 to 25, depending on the breed, which can have different retina configurations.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Fovea_centralis" title="Fovea centralis">fovea centralis</a> area of the eye is attached to a <a href="/wiki/Axon" title="Axon">nerve fiber</a>, and is the most sensitive to <a href="/wiki/Photon" title="Photon">photons</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Additionally, a study found that dogs' <a href="/wiki/Visual_acuity" title="Visual acuity">visual acuity</a> was up to eight times less effective than a human, and their ability to discriminate levels of <a href="/wiki/Brightness" title="Brightness">brightness</a> was about two times worse than a human.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>While the human brain is dominated by a large <a href="/wiki/Visual_cortex" title="Visual cortex">visual cortex</a>, the dog brain is dominated by a large <a href="/wiki/Olfactory_system" title="Olfactory system">olfactory cortex</a>. Dogs have roughly forty times more <a href="/wiki/Olfactory_receptor" title="Olfactory receptor">smell-sensitive receptors</a> than humans, ranging from about 125<span class="nowrap"> </span>million to nearly 300<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in some dog breeds, such as <a href="/wiki/Bloodhound" title="Bloodhound">bloodhounds</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This sense of smell is the most prominent sense of the species; it detects chemical changes in the environment, allowing dogs to pinpoint the location of mating partners, potential stressors, resources, etc.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs also have an acute sense of hearing up to four times greater than that of humans. They can pick up the slightest sounds from about 400 m (1,300 ft) compared to 90 m (300 ft) for humans.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Dogs have stiff, deeply embedded hairs known as <a href="/wiki/Whisker" class="mw-redirect" title="Whisker">whiskers</a> that sense atmospheric changes, vibrations, and objects not visible in low light conditions. The lower most part of whiskers hold more receptor cells than other hair types, which help in alerting dogs of objects that could collide with the nose, ears, and jaw. Whiskers likely also facilitate the movement of food towards the mouth.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Coat">Coat</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_coat" title="Dog coat">Dog coat</a></div><p>The <a href="/wiki/Pelage" class="mw-redirect" title="Pelage">coats</a> of domestic dogs are of two varieties: "double" being common in dogs (as well as wolves) originating from colder climates, made up of a coarse <a href="/wiki/Guard_hair" title="Guard hair">guard hair</a> and a soft <a href="/wiki/Down_hair" class="mw-redirect" title="Down hair">down hair</a>, or "single", with the topcoat only. Breeds may have an occasional "blaze", stripe, or "star" of white fur on their chest or underside.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe20042223_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe20042223-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Premature graying can occur in dogs as early as one year of age; this is associated with <a href="/wiki/Impulsivity" title="Impulsivity">impulsive behaviors</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anxiety" title="Anxiety">anxiety</a> behaviors, and fear of unfamiliar noise, people, or animals.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some dog breeds are hairless, while others have a very thick corded coat. The coats of certain breeds are often groomed to a characteristic style, for example, the <a href="/wiki/Yorkshire_Terrier" title="Yorkshire Terrier">Yorkshire Terrier</a>'s "show cut".<sup id="cite_ref-:3_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Dewclaw">Dewclaw</h3></div>
<p>A dog's <a href="/wiki/Dewclaw" title="Dewclaw">dewclaw</a> is the fifth <a href="/wiki/Digit_(anatomy)" title="Digit (anatomy)">digit</a> in its forelimb and hind legs. Dewclaws on the forelimbs are attached by bone and ligament, while the dewclaws on the hind legs are attached only by skin. Most dogs are not born with dewclaws in their hind legs, and some are without them in their forelimbs. Dogs' dewclaws consist of the <a href="/wiki/Phalanx_bone" title="Phalanx bone">proximal phalanges and distal phalanges</a>. Some publications theorize that dewclaws in wolves, who usually do not have dewclaws, were a sign of hybridization with dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Tail">Tail</h3></div>
<p>A dog's tail is the terminal appendage of the <a href="/wiki/Vertebral_column" class="mw-redirect" title="Vertebral column">vertebral column</a>, which is made up of a string of 5 to 23 <a href="/wiki/Vertebra" title="Vertebra">vertebrae</a> enclosed in muscles and skin that support the dog's back extensor muscles. One of the primary functions of a dog's tail is to communicate their emotional state.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The tail also helps the dog maintain balance by putting its weight on the opposite side of the dog's tilt, and it can also help the dog spread its <a href="/wiki/Anal_gland" title="Anal gland">anal gland</a>'s scent through the tail's position and movement.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs can have a <a href="/wiki/Violet_gland" title="Violet gland">violet gland</a> (or supracaudal gland) characterized by <a href="/wiki/Sebaceous_gland" title="Sebaceous gland">sebaceous glands</a> on the dorsal surface of their tails; in some breeds, it may be vestigial or absent. The enlargement of the violet gland in the tail, which can create a <a href="/wiki/Hair_loss" title="Hair loss">bald spot from hair loss</a>, can be caused by <a href="/wiki/Cushing%27s_syndrome_(veterinary)" title="Cushing's syndrome (veterinary)">Cushing's disease</a> or an excess of sebum from <a href="/wiki/Androgen" title="Androgen">androgens</a> in the sebaceous glands.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:BlkStdSchnauzer2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/BlkStdSchnauzer2.jpg/250px-BlkStdSchnauzer2.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="203" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/BlkStdSchnauzer2.jpg/375px-BlkStdSchnauzer2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3b/BlkStdSchnauzer2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="477" data-file-height="387"></a><figcaption>A black <a href="/wiki/Standard_Schnauzer" title="Standard Schnauzer">Standard Schnauzer</a> with a docked tail</figcaption></figure>
<p>A study suggests that dogs show asymmetric tail-wagging responses to different emotive stimuli. "Stimuli that could be expected to elicit approach tendencies seem to be associated with [a] higher amplitude of tail-wagging movements to the right side".<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs can injure themselves by wagging their tails forcefully; this condition is called <i>kennel tail</i>, <i>happy tail</i>, <i>bleeding tail</i>, or <i>splitting tail</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In some <a href="/wiki/Hunting_dog" title="Hunting dog">hunting dogs</a>, the tail is traditionally <a href="/wiki/Docking_(dog)" title="Docking (dog)">docked</a> to avoid injuries. Some dogs can be born without tails because of a DNA variant in the <a href="/wiki/T-box_transcription_factor_T" title="T-box transcription factor T">T gene</a>, which can also result in a congenitally short (bobtail) tail.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Tail docking is opposed by many veterinary and animal welfare organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/American_Veterinary_Medical_Association" title="American Veterinary Medical Association">American Veterinary Medical Association</a><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/British_Veterinary_Association" title="British Veterinary Association">British Veterinary Association</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Evidence from veterinary practices and <a href="/wiki/Questionnaire" title="Questionnaire">questionnaires</a> showed that around 500 dogs would need to have their tail docked to prevent one injury.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Health">Health</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_health" title="Dog health">Dog health</a></div>
<p>Numerous disorders have been known to affect dogs. Some are <a href="/wiki/Congenital" class="mw-redirect" title="Congenital">congenital</a> and others are acquired. Dogs can acquire upper respiratory tract diseases including diseases that affect the <a href="/wiki/Nasal_cavity" title="Nasal cavity">nasal cavity</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Larynx" title="Larynx">larynx</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Trachea" title="Trachea">trachea</a>; lower respiratory tract diseases which includes <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Pulmonary disease">pulmonary disease</a> and acute respiratory diseases; <a href="/wiki/Heart_diseases" class="mw-redirect" title="Heart diseases">heart diseases</a> which includes any <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardiovascular">cardiovascular</a> inflammation or dysfunction of the heart; <a href="/wiki/Hematopoiesis" class="mw-redirect" title="Hematopoiesis">haemopoietic diseases</a> including <a href="/wiki/Anaemia" class="mw-redirect" title="Anaemia">anaemia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clotting_disorders" class="mw-redirect" title="Clotting disorders">clotting disorders</a>; <a href="/wiki/Gastrointestinal_disease" title="Gastrointestinal disease">gastrointestinal disease</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Diarrhoea" class="mw-redirect" title="Diarrhoea">diarrhoea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gastric_dilatation_volvulus" title="Gastric dilatation volvulus">gastric dilatation volvulus</a>; <a href="/wiki/Hepatic_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Hepatic disease">hepatic disease</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Portosystemic_shunts_in_animals" title="Portosystemic shunts in animals">portosystemic shunts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liver_failure" title="Liver failure">liver failure</a>; <a href="/wiki/Pancreatic_disease" title="Pancreatic disease">pancreatic disease</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Pancreatitis_(veterinary)" title="Pancreatitis (veterinary)">pancreatitis</a>; <a href="/wiki/Renal_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Renal disease">renal disease</a>; lower urinary tract disease such as <a href="/wiki/Cystitis" class="mw-redirect" title="Cystitis">cystitis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urolithiasis" class="mw-redirect" title="Urolithiasis">urolithiasis</a>; <a href="/wiki/Endocrine_disorders" class="mw-redirect" title="Endocrine disorders">endocrine disorders</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Diabetes_in_dogs" title="Diabetes in dogs">diabetes mellitus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cushing%27s_syndrome_(veterinary)" title="Cushing's syndrome (veterinary)">Cushing's syndrome</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hypoadrenocorticism_in_dogs" title="Hypoadrenocorticism in dogs">hypoadrenocorticism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hypothyroidism_in_dogs" title="Hypothyroidism in dogs">hypothyroidism</a>; <a href="/wiki/Nervous_system" title="Nervous system">nervous system</a> diseases such as <a href="/wiki/Seizures" class="mw-redirect" title="Seizures">seizures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spinal_injury" class="mw-redirect" title="Spinal injury">spinal injury</a>; <a href="/wiki/Musculoskeletal_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Musculoskeletal disease">musculoskeletal disease</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Arthritis" title="Arthritis">arthritis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Myopathies" class="mw-redirect" title="Myopathies">myopathies</a>; <a href="/wiki/Dog_skin_disorders" title="Dog skin disorders">dermatological disorders</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Alopecia" class="mw-redirect" title="Alopecia">alopecia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pyoderma" title="Pyoderma">pyoderma</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ophthalmological_disease&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Ophthalmological disease (page does not exist)">ophthalmological diseases</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Conjunctivitis" title="Conjunctivitis">conjunctivitis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Glaucoma" title="Glaucoma">glaucoma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Entropion" title="Entropion">entropion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Progressive_retinal_atrophy" title="Progressive retinal atrophy">progressive retinal atrophy</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Neoplasia" class="mw-redirect" title="Neoplasia">neoplasia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-health_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-health-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Common dog parasites are <a href="/wiki/Lice" class="mw-redirect" title="Lice">lice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flea" title="Flea">fleas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fly_larvae" class="mw-redirect" title="Fly larvae">fly larvae</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tick" title="Tick">ticks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mite" title="Mite">mites</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cestode" class="mw-redirect" title="Cestode">cestodes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nematode" title="Nematode">nematodes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Coccidia" title="Coccidia">coccidia</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Taenia_(flatworm)" title="Taenia (flatworm)">Taenia</a></i> is a notable genus with 5 species in which dogs are the <a href="/wiki/Definitive_host" class="mw-redirect" title="Definitive host">definitive host</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Additionally, dogs are a source of <a href="/wiki/Zoonoses" class="mw-redirect" title="Zoonoses">zoonoses</a> for humans. They are responsible for 99% of <a href="/wiki/Rabies" title="Rabies">rabies</a> cases worldwide;<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> however, in some developed countries such as the UK, rabies is absent from dogs and is instead only transmitted by bats.<sup id="cite_ref-bsava_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bsava-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Other common zoonoses are <a href="/wiki/Hydatid_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydatid disease">hydatid disease</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leptospirosis" title="Leptospirosis">leptospirosis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pasteurellosis" title="Pasteurellosis">pasteurellosis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ringworm" class="mw-redirect" title="Ringworm">ringworm</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Toxocariasis" title="Toxocariasis">toxocariasis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-bsava_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bsava-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Common infections in dogs include <a href="/wiki/Canine_adenovirus" class="mw-redirect" title="Canine adenovirus">canine adenovirus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canine_distemper_virus" class="mw-redirect" title="Canine distemper virus">canine distemper virus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canine_parvovirus" title="Canine parvovirus">canine parvovirus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leptospirosis" title="Leptospirosis">leptospirosis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canine_influenza" title="Canine influenza">canine influenza</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Canine_coronavirus" title="Canine coronavirus">canine coronavirus</a>. All of these conditions have vaccines available.<sup id="cite_ref-bsava_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bsava-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Dogs are the companion animal most frequently reported for exposure to <a href="/wiki/Toxin" title="Toxin">toxins</a>. Most poisonings are accidental and over 80% of reports of exposure to the <a href="/wiki/ASPCA" class="mw-redirect" title="ASPCA">ASPCA</a> animal poisoning hotline are due to oral exposure. The most common substances people report exposure to are: pharmaceuticals, toxic foods, and <a href="/wiki/Rodenticides" class="mw-redirect" title="Rodenticides">rodenticides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Data from the Pet Poison Helpline shows that human drugs are the most frequent cause of toxicosis death. The most common household products ingested are cleaning products. Most food related poisonings involved <a href="/wiki/Theobromine_poisoning" title="Theobromine poisoning">theobromine poisoning</a> (chocolate). Other common food poisonings include <a href="/wiki/Xylitol" title="Xylitol">xylitol</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Vitis" title="Vitis">Vitis</a></i> (grapes, raisins, etc.), and <i><a href="/wiki/Allium" title="Allium">Allium</a></i> (garlic, onions, etc.). <a href="/wiki/Pyrethrin" title="Pyrethrin">Pyrethrin</a> insecticides were the most common cause of pesticide poisoning. <a href="/wiki/Metaldehyde" title="Metaldehyde">Metaldehyde</a>, a common pesticide for snails and slugs, typically causes severe outcomes when ingested by dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Neoplasia" class="mw-redirect" title="Neoplasia">Neoplasia</a> is the most common cause of death for dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-death_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-death-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Other common causes of death are <a href="/wiki/Heart_failure" title="Heart failure">heart</a> and <a href="/wiki/Renal_failure" class="mw-redirect" title="Renal failure">renal failure</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-death_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-death-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Their <a href="/wiki/Pathology" title="Pathology">pathology</a> is similar to that of humans, as is their <a href="/wiki/Immune_response" title="Immune response">response</a> to treatment and their outcomes. Genes found in humans to be responsible for disorders are investigated in dogs as being the cause and vice versa.<sup id="cite_ref-Ostrander2019_28-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ostrander2019-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Lifespan">Lifespan</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Aging_in_dogs" title="Aging in dogs">Aging in dogs</a></div>
<p>The typical lifespan of dogs varies widely among breeds, but the median longevity (the age at which half the dogs in a population have died and half are still alive) is approximately 12.7 years.<sup id="cite_ref-Montoya_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montoya-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Obesity correlates negatively with longevity with one study finding obese dogs to have a life expectancy approximately a year and a half less than dogs with a healthy weight.<sup id="cite_ref-Montoya_74-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Montoya-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In a 2024 UK study analyzing 584,734 dogs, it was concluded that purebred dogs lived longer than crossbred dogs, challenging the previous notion of the latter having the higher life expectancies. The authors noted that their study included "<a href="/wiki/Designer_dog" class="mw-redirect" title="Designer dog">designer dogs</a>" as crossbred and that purebred dogs were typically given better care than their crossbred counterparts, which likely influenced the outcome of the study.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Other studies also show that fully mongrel dogs live about a year longer on average than dogs with pedigrees.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Furthermore, small dogs with longer muzzles have been shown to have higher lifespans than larger medium-sized dogs with much more depressed muzzles.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> For free-ranging dogs, less than 1 in 5 reach sexual maturity,<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the median life expectancy for feral dogs is less than half of dogs living with humans.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Reproduction">Reproduction</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Canine_reproduction" title="Canine reproduction">Canine reproduction</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Dogs_mating_2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Dogs_mating_2.jpg/250px-Dogs_mating_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="143" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Dogs_mating_2.jpg/500px-Dogs_mating_2.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="872" data-file-height="498"></a><figcaption>Two dogs <a href="/wiki/Canine_reproduction" title="Canine reproduction">tied after mating</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>In domestic dogs, <a href="/wiki/Sexual_maturity" title="Sexual maturity">sexual maturity</a> happens around six months to one year for both males and females, although this can be delayed until up to two years of age for some large breeds. This is the time at which female dogs will have their first <a href="/wiki/Estrous_cycle" title="Estrous cycle">estrous cycle</a>, characterized by their <a href="/wiki/Vulva" title="Vulva">vulvas</a> swelling and producing <a href="/wiki/Vaginal_discharge" title="Vaginal discharge">discharges</a>, usually lasting between 4 and 20 days.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> They will experience subsequent estrous cycles semiannually, during which the body prepares for <a href="/wiki/Pregnancy_(mammals)" title="Pregnancy (mammals)">pregnancy</a>. At the peak of the cycle, females will become estrous, mentally and physically receptive to <a href="/wiki/Canine_tying" class="mw-redirect" title="Canine tying">copulation</a>. Because the <a href="/wiki/Ovum" class="mw-redirect" title="Ovum">ova</a> survive and can be fertilized for a week after ovulation, more than one male can sire the same litter.<sup id="cite_ref-ADW_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ADW-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Fertilization typically occurs two to five days after ovulation. After <a href="/wiki/Ejaculation" title="Ejaculation">ejaculation</a>, the dogs are <a href="/wiki/Canine_reproduction" title="Canine reproduction">coitally tied</a> for around 530 minutes because of the male's <a href="/wiki/Bulbus_glandis" title="Bulbus glandis">bulbus glandis</a> swelling and the female's <a href="/wiki/Bulb_of_vestibule" title="Bulb of vestibule">constrictor vestibuli</a> contracting; the male will continue ejaculating until they untie naturally due to <a href="/wiki/Muscle_contraction" title="Muscle contraction">muscle relaxation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 1416 days after ovulation, the embryo attaches to the <a href="/wiki/Uterus" title="Uterus">uterus</a>, and after seven to eight more days, a heartbeat is detectable.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs bear their litters roughly 58 to 68 days after <a href="/wiki/Fertilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Fertilization">fertilization</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-ADW_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ADW-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with an average of 63 days, although the length of <a href="/wiki/Gestation" title="Gestation">gestation</a> can vary. An average litter consists of about six <a href="/wiki/Puppy" title="Puppy">puppies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Neutering">Neutering</h4></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Neutering" title="Neutering">Neutering</a> is the sterilization of animals via <a href="/wiki/Gonadectomy" title="Gonadectomy">gonadectomy</a>, which is an <a href="/wiki/Orchidectomy" class="mw-redirect" title="Orchidectomy">orchidectomy</a> (castration) in dogs and <a href="/wiki/Ovariohysterectomy" class="mw-redirect" title="Ovariohysterectomy">ovariohysterectomy</a> (spay) in bitches. Neutering reduces problems caused by <a href="/wiki/Hypersexuality" title="Hypersexuality">hypersexuality</a>, especially in male dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Spayed females are less likely to develop <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancers</a> affecting the <a href="/wiki/Mammary_gland" title="Mammary gland">mammary glands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ovary" title="Ovary">ovaries</a>, and other <a href="/wiki/Sex_organ" title="Sex organ">reproductive organs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, neutering increases the risk of <a href="/wiki/Urinary_incontinence" title="Urinary incontinence">urinary incontinence</a> in bitches,<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Prostate_cancer" title="Prostate cancer">prostate cancer</a> in dogs,<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Osteosarcoma" title="Osteosarcoma">osteosarcoma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hemangiosarcoma" title="Hemangiosarcoma">hemangiosarcoma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anterior_cruciate_ligament_injury" title="Anterior cruciate ligament injury">cruciate ligament rupture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pyometra" title="Pyometra">pyometra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Obesity_in_pets" title="Obesity in pets">obesity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus" class="mw-redirect" title="Diabetes mellitus">diabetes mellitus</a> in either sex.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Neutering is the most common surgical procedure in dogs less than a year old in the US and is seen as a control method for overpopulation. Neutering often occurs as early as 614 weeks in shelters in the US.<sup id="cite_ref-neuter_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-neuter-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/American_Society_for_the_Prevention_of_Cruelty_to_Animals" title="American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals">American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals</a> (ASPCA) advises that dogs not intended for further breeding should be neutered so that they do not have undesired puppies that may later be euthanized.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> However, the Society for Theriogenology and the American College of Theriogenologists made a joint statement that opposes mandatory neutering; they said that the cause of overpopulation in the US is cultural.<sup id="cite_ref-neuter_94-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-neuter-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Neutering is less common in most European countries, especially in <a href="/wiki/Nordic_countries" title="Nordic countries">Nordic countries</a>except for the UK, where it is common. In Norway, neutering is illegal unless for the benefit of the animal's health (e.g., ovariohysterectomy in case of ovarian or uterine neoplasia). Some European countries have similar laws to Norway, but their wording either explicitly allows for neutering for controlling reproduction or it is allowed in practice or by contradiction through other laws. Italy and Portugal have passed recent laws that promote it. Germany forbids early age neutering, but neutering is still allowed at the usual age. In Romania, neutering is mandatory except for when a pedigree to select breeds can be shown.<sup id="cite_ref-neuter_94-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-neuter-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Inbreeding_depression">Inbreeding depression</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Inbreeding_depression" title="Inbreeding depression">Inbreeding depression</a></div>
<p>A common breeding practice for pet dogs is to <a href="/wiki/Inbreeding" title="Inbreeding">mate them between close relatives</a> (e.g., between half- and full-siblings).<sup id="cite_ref-Leroy_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leroy-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In a study of seven dog breeds (the <a href="/wiki/Bernese_Mountain_Dog" title="Bernese Mountain Dog">Bernese Mountain Dog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basset_Hound" title="Basset Hound">Basset Hound</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cairn_Terrier" title="Cairn Terrier">Cairn Terrier</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brittany_(dog)" class="mw-redirect" title="Brittany (dog)">Brittany</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_Shepherd" title="German Shepherd">German Shepherd Dog</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonberger" title="Leonberger">Leonberger</a>, and <a href="/wiki/West_Highland_White_Terrier" title="West Highland White Terrier">West Highland White Terrier</a>), it was found that inbreeding decreases litter size and survival.<sup id="cite_ref-pmid25475165_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid25475165-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Another analysis of data on 42,855 <a href="/wiki/Dachshund" title="Dachshund">Dachshund</a> litters found that as the <a href="/wiki/Inbreeding_coefficient" class="mw-redirect" title="Inbreeding coefficient">inbreeding coefficient</a> increased, litter size decreased and the percentage of stillborn puppies increased, thus indicating inbreeding depression.<sup id="cite_ref-pmid15803761_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid15803761-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In a study of <a href="/wiki/Boxer_(dog)" class="mw-redirect" title="Boxer (dog)">Boxer</a> litters, 22% of puppies died before reaching 7 weeks of age. Stillbirth was the most frequent cause of death, followed by infection. Mortality due to infection increased significantly with increases in inbreeding.<sup id="cite_ref-Beek_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beek-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Behavior">Behavior</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_behavior" title="Dog behavior">Dog behavior</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Dog_intelligence" title="Dog intelligence">Dog intelligence</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Dog_behavior#Behavior_compared_with_other_canids" title="Dog behavior">Dog behavior  Behavior compared with other canids</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Dog_behavior" title="Dog behavior">Dog behavior</a> has been shaped by millennia of contact with humans. They have acquired the ability to understand and communicate with humans and are uniquely attuned to human behaviors.<sup id="cite_ref-levitis2009_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-levitis2009-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-berns2012_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-berns2012-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Behavioral scientists suggest that a set of social-cognitive abilities in domestic dogs that are not possessed by the dog's canine relatives or other highly intelligent mammals, such as <a href="/wiki/Great_ape" class="mw-redirect" title="Great ape">great apes</a>, are parallel to children's social-cognitive skills.<sup id="cite_ref-tomasello2009_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tomasello2009-104"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>  Dogs have about twice the number of neurons in their cerebral cortexes than what cats have, which suggests they could be about twice as intelligent.<sup id="cite_ref-ng_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ng-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>
Most domestic animals were initially bred for the production of goods. Dogs, on the other hand, were selectively bred for desirable behavioral traits.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cagan2016_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cagan2016-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2016, a study found that only 11 fixed genes showed variation between wolves and dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These gene variations indicate the occurrence of <a href="/wiki/Artificial_selection" class="mw-redirect" title="Artificial selection">artificial selection</a> and the subsequent divergence of behavior and anatomical features. These genes have been shown to affect the <a href="/wiki/Catecholamine#Biosynthesis" title="Catecholamine">catecholamine synthesis</a> pathway, with the majority of the genes affecting the <a href="/wiki/Fight-or-flight_response" title="Fight-or-flight response">fight-or-flight response</a><sup id="cite_ref-cagan2016_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cagan2016-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> (i.e., selection for <a href="/wiki/Tame_animal" title="Tame animal">tameness</a>) and emotional processing.<sup id="cite_ref-cagan2016_107-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cagan2016-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Compared to their wolf counterparts, dogs tend to be less timid and less aggressive, though some of these genes have been associated with aggression in certain dog breeds.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cagan2016_107-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cagan2016-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Traits of high sociability and lack of fear in dogs may include genetic modifications related to <a href="/wiki/Williams-Beuren_syndrome" class="mw-redirect" title="Williams-Beuren syndrome">Williams-Beuren syndrome</a> in humans, which cause <a href="/wiki/Hypersociability" title="Hypersociability">hypersociability</a> at the expense of <a href="/wiki/Problem_solving" title="Problem solving">problem-solving ability</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-sciencemag_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sciencemag-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In a 2023 study of 58 dogs, some dogs classified as <a href="/wiki/Attention_deficit_hyperactivity_disorder" title="Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder">attention deficit hyperactivity disorder</a>-like showed lower <a href="/wiki/Serotonin" title="Serotonin">serotonin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dopamine" title="Dopamine">dopamine</a> concentrations.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A similar study claims that hyperactivity is more common in male and young dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A dog can become aggressive because of trauma or abuse, fear or anxiety, territorial protection, or protecting an item it considers valuable.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Acute_stress_reaction" title="Acute stress reaction">Acute stress reactions</a> from <a href="/wiki/Post-traumatic_stress_disorder" title="Post-traumatic stress disorder">post-traumatic stress disorder</a> (PTSD) seen in dogs can evolve into <a href="/wiki/Chronic_stress" title="Chronic stress">chronic stress</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Police dogs with PTSD can often refuse to work.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><span><span class="mw-tmh-player video"><video id="mwe_player_0_placeholder" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/2022-07-20_LJUBLJANA_%C5%A0PICA_CARNIVORA_Canis_lupus_familiaris_DOMA%C4%8CI_PES.webm/300px--2022-07-20_LJUBLJANA_%C5%A0PICA_CARNIVORA_Canis_lupus_familiaris_DOMA%C4%8CI_PES.webm.jpg" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="mw-file-element" width="300" height="169" data-durationhint="30" data-mwtitle="2022-07-20_LJUBLJANA_PICA_CARNIVORA_Canis_lupus_familiaris_DOMAI_PES.webm" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" resource="/wiki/File:2022-07-20_LJUBLJANA_%C5%A0PICA_CARNIVORA_Canis_lupus_familiaris_DOMA%C4%8CI_PES.webm" playsinline="" disabled="disabled" tabindex="-1"
