style="aspect-ratio: 300 / 169;"></video><a class="mw-tmh-play" href="/wiki/File:2022-07-20_LJUBLJANA_%C5%A0PICA_CARNIVORA_Canis_lupus_familiaris_DOMA%C4%8CI_PES.webm" title="Play video" role="button"><span class="mw-tmh-play-icon notheme"></span></a><span class="mw-tmh-duration mw-tmh-label"><span class="sr-only">Duration: 30 seconds.</span><span aria-hidden="true">0:30</span></span></span></span><a href="/wiki/File:2022-07-20_LJUBLJANA_%C5%A0PICA_CARNIVORA_Canis_lupus_familiaris_DOMA%C4%8CI_PES.webm" class="mw-file-magnify"></a><figcaption>Dog swimming over to catch a ball</figcaption></figure>
<p>Dogs have a natural instinct called <i><a href="/wiki/Prey_drive" title="Prey drive">prey drive</a></i> (the term is chiefly used to describe <a href="/wiki/Dog_training" title="Dog training">training dogs</a>' habits) which can be influenced by breeding. These instincts can drive dogs to consider objects or other animals to be prey or drive possessive behavior. These traits have been enhanced in some breeds so that they may be used to hunt and kill <a href="/wiki/Vermin" title="Vermin">vermin</a> or other pests.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Puppies or dogs sometimes <a href="/wiki/Hoarding_(animal_behavior)" title="Hoarding (animal behavior)">bury food underground</a>. One study found that wolves outperformed dogs in finding food caches, likely due to a "difference in motivation" between wolves and dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some puppies and dogs engage in <a href="/wiki/Coprophagia" title="Coprophagia">coprophagy</a> out of habit, stress, for attention, or boredom; most of them will not do it later in life. A study hypothesizes that the behavior was inherited from wolves, a behavior likely evolved to lessen the presence of <a href="/wiki/Intestinal_parasite_infection" title="Intestinal parasite infection">intestinal parasites</a> in dens.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Most dogs can swim. In a study of 412 dogs, around 36.5% of the dogs could not swim; the other 63.5% were able to swim without a trainer in a <a href="/wiki/Swimming_pool" title="Swimming pool">swimming pool</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A study of 55 dogs found a correlation between swimming and 'improvement' of the hip <a href="/wiki/Osteoarthritis" title="Osteoarthritis">osteoarthritis joint</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Nursing">Nursing</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:S%C3%A4ugende_H%C3%BCndin.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/S%C3%A4ugende_H%C3%BCndin.JPG/250px-S%C3%A4ugende_H%C3%BCndin.JPG" decoding="async" width="250" height="182" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f1/S%C3%A4ugende_H%C3%BCndin.JPG/500px-S%C3%A4ugende_H%C3%BCndin.JPG 1.5x" data-file-width="1108" data-file-height="805"></a><figcaption>A bitch nursing her newborn puppies</figcaption></figure>
<p>The female dog (bitch) may produce <a href="/wiki/Colostrum" title="Colostrum">colostrum</a>, a type of milk high in nutrients and antibodies, 17 days before giving birth. Milk production lasts for around three months,<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:1_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and increases with litter size.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_123-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The dog can sometimes vomit and refuse food during <a href="/wiki/Birth" title="Birth">child contractions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the later stages of the dog's pregnancy, <a href="/wiki/Nesting_instinct" title="Nesting instinct">nesting behaviour</a> may occur.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Puppies are born with a <a href="/wiki/Fetal_membranes" title="Fetal membranes">protective fetal membrane</a> that the mother usually removes shortly after birth. Dogs can have the maternal instincts to start grooming their puppies, consume their puppies' feces, and protect their puppies, likely due to their hormonal state.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> While male-parent dogs can show more disinterested behaviour toward their own puppies,<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> most can play with the young pups as they would with other dogs or humans.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A bitch may abandon or attack her puppies or her male partner dog if she is stressed or in pain.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Intelligence">Intelligence</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_intelligence" title="Dog intelligence">Dog intelligence</a></div>
<p>Researchers have tested dogs' ability to perceive information, retain it as knowledge, and apply it to solve problems. Studies of two dogs suggest that dogs can learn by <a href="/wiki/Inference" title="Inference">inference</a>. A study with <a href="/wiki/Rico_(Border_Collie)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rico (Border Collie)">Rico</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Border_Collie" title="Border Collie">Border Collie</a>, showed that he knew the labels of over 200 different items. He inferred the names of novel things by exclusion learning and correctly retrieved those new items after four weeks of the initial exposure. A study of another Border Collie, Chaser, documented that he had learned the names and could associate them by verbal command with over 1,000 words.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>One study of canine cognitive abilities found that dogs' capabilities are similar to those of <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Common_chimpanzee" class="mw-redirect" title="Common chimpanzee">chimpanzees</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Cat" title="Cat">cats</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lea2018_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lea2018-132"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> One study of 18 household dogs found that the dogs could not distinguish food bowls at specific locations without distinguishing cues; the study stated that this indicates a lack of <a href="/wiki/Spatial_memory" title="Spatial memory">spatial memory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sluka2018_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sluka2018-133"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A study stated that dogs have a <a href="/wiki/Approximate_number_system" title="Approximate number system">visual sense for number</a>. The dogs showed a ratio-dependent <a href="/w/index.php?title=Neuron_activation&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Neuron activation (page does not exist)">activation</a> both for numerical values from 13 to larger than four.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Dogs demonstrate a <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_mind" title="Theory of mind">theory of mind</a> by engaging in deception.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Another experimental study showed evidence that Australian <a href="/wiki/Dingo" title="Dingo">dingos</a> can outperform domestic dogs in non-social problem-solving, indicating that domestic dogs may have lost much of their original problem-solving abilities once they joined humans.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Another study showed that dogs stared at humans after failing to complete an impossible version of the same task they had been trained to solve. Wolves, under the same situation, avoided staring at humans altogether.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Communication">Communication</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_communication" title="Dog communication">Dog communication</a></div>
