<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><figure class="mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/60px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="50" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg/120px-Gnome-mime-sound-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="160" data-file-height="160"></span><figcaption></figcaption></figure></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:A_dog_making_noises_and_barking.flac" title="File:A dog making noises and barking.flac">Dog sounds</a></div>
<div><span typeof="mw:File"><span><span class="mw-tmh-player audio mw-file-element" style="width:232px;"><audio id="mwe_player_1_placeholder" preload="none" data-mw-tmh="" class="" width="232" style="width:232px;" data-durationhint="15" data-mwtitle="A_dog_making_noises_and_barking.flac" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" playsinline="" disabled="disabled" tabindex="-1"></audio><a class="mw-tmh-play" href="/wiki/File:A_dog_making_noises_and_barking.flac" title="Play audio" role="button"><span class="mw-tmh-play-icon notheme"></span></a><span class="mw-tmh-duration mw-tmh-label"><span class="sr-only">Duration: 15 seconds.</span><span aria-hidden="true">0:15</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="description">A dog making noises and barking</div></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-abovebelow"><hr><i class="selfreference">Problems playing this file? See <a href="/wiki/Help:Media" title="Help:Media">media help</a>.</i></div>
</div>
<p>Dog communication is the transfer of information between dogs, as well as between dogs and humans.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Communication behaviors of dogs include eye gaze, facial expression,<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> vocalization, body posture (including movements of bodies and limbs), and gustatory communication (scents, pheromones, and taste). Dogs mark their <a href="/wiki/Territory_(animal)" title="Territory (animal)">territories</a> by urinating on them, which is more likely when entering a new environment.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Both sexes of dogs may also urinate to communicate anxiety or frustration, submissiveness, or when in exciting or relaxing situations.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Aroused dogs can be a result of the dogs' higher <a href="/wiki/Cortisol" title="Cortisol">cortisol</a> levels.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs begin socializing with other dogs by the time they reach the ages of 3 to 8 weeks, and at about 5 to 12 weeks of age, they alter their focus from dogs to humans.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Belly exposure in dogs can be a defensive behavior that can lead to a bite or to seek comfort.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Humans communicate with dogs by using vocalization, hand signals, and body posture. With their acute sense of hearing, dogs rely on the auditory aspect of communication for understanding and responding to various cues, including the distinctive <a href="/wiki/Bark_(sound)" title="Bark (sound)">barking</a> patterns that convey different messages. A study using <a href="/wiki/Functional_magnetic_resonance_imaging" title="Functional magnetic resonance imaging">functional magnetic resonance imaging</a> (fMRI) has shown that dogs respond to both vocal and nonvocal voices using the brain's region towards the <a href="/wiki/Cerebral_hemisphere" title="Cerebral hemisphere">temporal pole</a>, similar to that of humans' brains. Most dogs also looked significantly longer at the face whose expression matched the <a href="/wiki/Valence_(psychology)" title="Valence (psychology)">valence of vocalization</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Andics2014_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Andics2014-147"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A study of <a href="/wiki/Caudate_nucleus" title="Caudate nucleus">caudate responses</a> shows that dogs tend to respond more positively to social rewards than to food rewards.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Ecology">Ecology</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Population">Population</h3></div>
<p>The dog is the most widely abundant large <a href="/wiki/Carnivora" title="Carnivora">carnivoran</a> living in the human environment.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-151"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2020, the estimated global dog population was between 700 million and 1 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the same year, a study found the dog to be the most popular pet in the United States, as they were present in 34 out of every 100 homes.<sup id="cite_ref-:5_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:5-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> About 20% of the dog population live in <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed countries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lord2013_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lord2013-154"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing world</a>, it is estimated that three-quarters of the world's dog population lives in the developing world as <a href="/wiki/Feral" title="Feral">feral</a>, <a href="/wiki/Free-ranging_dog" title="Free-ranging dog">village</a>, or community dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Most of these dogs live as <a href="/wiki/Scavenger" title="Scavenger">scavengers</a> and have never been owned by humans, with one study showing that village dogs' most common response when approached by strangers is to run away (52%) or respond aggressively (11%).<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Competitors">Competitors</h3></div>
<p>Feral and <a href="/wiki/Free-ranging_dog" title="Free-ranging dog">free-ranging dogs</a>' potential to compete with other large carnivores is limited by their strong association with humans.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_151-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-151"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although wolves are known to kill dogs, wolves tend to live in pairs in areas where they are highly persecuted, giving them a disadvantage when facing large dog groups.<sup id="cite_ref-lescureaux2014_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lescureaux2014-157"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoitaniMech2003259264_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoitaniMech2003259264-158"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In some instances, wolves have displayed an uncharacteristic fearlessness of humans and buildings when attacking dogs, to the extent that they have to be beaten off or killed.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although the numbers of dogs killed each year are relatively low, there is still a fear among humans of wolves entering villages and farmyards to take dogs, and losses of dogs to wolves have led to demands for more liberal wolf hunting regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-lescureaux2014_157-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lescureaux2014-157"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Coyote" title="Coyote">Coyotes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Big_cat" title="Big cat">big cats</a> have also been known to attack dogs. In particular, <a href="/wiki/Leopard" title="Leopard">leopards</a> are known to have a preference for dogs and have been recorded to kill and consume them, no matter their size.<sup id="cite_ref-Leopard_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leopard-160"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Siberian_tiger" title="Siberian tiger">Siberian tigers</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Amur_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Amur river">Amur river</a> region have killed dogs in the middle of villages. They will not tolerate wolves as competitors within their territories, and the tigers could be considering dogs in the same way.<sup id="cite_ref-Gompper2013_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gompper2013-161"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Striped_hyena" title="Striped hyena">Striped hyenas</a> are known to kill dogs in their range.<sup id="cite_ref-Striped_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Striped-162"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs as introduced predators have affected the ecology of <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand" title="New Zealand">New Zealand</a>, which lacked indigenous land-based mammals before human settlement.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs have made 11 <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">vertebrate</a> species extinct and are identified as a 'potential threat' to at least 188 threatened species worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs have also been linked to the extinction of 156 animal species.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs have been documented to have killed a few birds of the endangered species, the <a href="/wiki/Kagu" title="Kagu">kagu</a>, in <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Diet">Diet</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Dog_food" title="Dog food">Dog food</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Golden_retriever_eating_pigs_foot.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Golden_retriever_eating_pigs_foot.jpg/250px-Golden_retriever_eating_pigs_foot.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="330" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Golden_retriever_eating_pigs_foot.jpg/500px-Golden_retriever_eating_pigs_foot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/af/Golden_retriever_eating_pigs_foot.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="659"></a><figcaption>A <a href="/wiki/Golden_retriever" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden retriever">golden retriever</a> gnawing on a pig's foot bone</figcaption></figure>
<p>Dogs are typically described as <a href="/wiki/Omnivore" title="Omnivore">omnivores</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ADW_83-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ADW-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Compared to wolves, dogs from agricultural societies have <a href="/wiki/Amylase#Evolution" title="Amylase">extra copies of amylase</a> and other genes involved in starch digestion that contribute to an increased ability to thrive on a starch-rich diet.<sup id="cite_ref-axelssonetal2013_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-axelssonetal2013-169"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Similar to humans, some dog breeds produce amylase in their <a href="/wiki/Saliva" title="Saliva">saliva</a> and are classified as having a high-starch diet.<sup id="cite_ref-Pajic2019_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pajic2019-170"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Despite being an omnivore, dogs are only able to conjugate <a href="/wiki/Bile_acid" title="Bile acid">bile acid</a> with <a href="/wiki/Taurine" title="Taurine">taurine</a>. They must get <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_D" title="Vitamin D">vitamin D</a> from their diet.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Of the <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acid" title="Essential amino acid">twenty-one amino acids common to all life forms</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Selenocysteine" title="Selenocysteine">selenocysteine</a>), dogs cannot synthesize ten: <a href="/wiki/Arginine" title="Arginine">arginine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Histidine" title="Histidine">histidine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isoleucine" title="Isoleucine">isoleucine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leucine" title="Leucine">leucine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lysine" title="Lysine">lysine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Methionine" title="Methionine">methionine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phenylalanine" title="Phenylalanine">phenylalanine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Threonine" title="Threonine">threonine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tryptophan" title="Tryptophan">tryptophan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Valine" title="Valine">valine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Like cats, dogs require arginine to maintain <a href="/wiki/Nitrogen_balance" title="Nitrogen balance">nitrogen balance</a>. These nutritional requirements place dogs halfway between carnivores and omnivores.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Range">Range</h3></div>
<p>As a domesticated or semi-domesticated animal, the dog has notable exceptions of presence in:
</p>
<ul><li>The <a href="/wiki/Aboriginal_Tasmanians" title="Aboriginal Tasmanians">Aboriginal Tasmanians</a>, who were separated from Australia before the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Dingo" title="Dingo">dingos</a> on that continent<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Andamanese_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Andamanese peoples">Andamanese peoples</a>, who were isolated when <a href="/wiki/Sea_level_rise" title="Sea level rise">rising sea levels</a> covered the <a href="/wiki/Land_bridge" title="Land bridge">land bridge</a> to Myanmar<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>The <a href="/wiki/Fuegians" title="Fuegians">Fuegians</a>, who instead domesticated the <a href="/wiki/Fuegian_dog" title="Fuegian dog">Fuegian dog</a>, an already extinct different canid species<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>Individual Pacific islands whose maritime settlers did not bring dogs or where the dogs died out after original settlement, notably the <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Islands" title="Mariana Islands">Mariana Islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">Palau</a><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and most of the <a href="/wiki/Caroline_Islands" title="Caroline Islands">Caroline Islands</a> with exceptions such as <a href="/wiki/Fais_Island" title="Fais Island">Fais Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nukuoro" title="Nukuoro">Nukuoro</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Islands" title="Marshall Islands">Marshall Islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Urban_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Urban-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Gilbert_Islands" title="Gilbert Islands">Gilbert Islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Urban_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Urban-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/New_Caledonia" title="New Caledonia">New Caledonia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Matisoo-Smith_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matisoo-Smith-184"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vanuatu" title="Vanuatu">Vanuatu</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Matisoo-Smith_184-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matisoo-Smith-184"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forster_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forster-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tonga" title="Tonga">Tonga</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Forster_185-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forster-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marquesas" class="mw-redirect" title="Marquesas">Marquesas</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Forster_185-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forster-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mangaia" title="Mangaia">Mangaia</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Cook_Islands" title="Cook Islands">Cook Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rapa_Iti" title="Rapa Iti">Rapa Iti</a> in <a href="/wiki/French_Polynesia" title="French Polynesia">French Polynesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">Easter Island</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Forster_185-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forster-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Chatham_Islands" title="Chatham Islands">Chatham Islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Island" title="Pitcairn Island">Pitcairn Island</a> (settled by the <a href="/wiki/Mutiny_on_the_Bounty" title="Mutiny on the Bounty"><i>Bounty</i> mutineers</a>, who killed off their dogs to escape discovery by passing ships).<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul><p>
Dogs were introduced to <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a> as <a href="/wiki/Sled_dog" title="Sled dog">sled dogs</a>. Starting practice in December 1993, dogs were later outlawed by the <a href="/wiki/Protocol_on_Environmental_Protection_to_the_Antarctic_Treaty" title="Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty">Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty international agreement</a> due to the possible risk of spreading infections.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><div style="clear:both;" class=""></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Roles_with_humans">Roles with humans</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human%E2%80%93canine_bond" title="Humancanine bond">Humancanine bond</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Domestication_of_the_dog" title="Domestication of the dog">domesticated dog</a> originated as a <a href="/wiki/Predator" class="mw-redirect" title="Predator">predator</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scavenger" title="Scavenger">scavenger</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> They inherited complex behaviors, such as <a href="/wiki/Bite_inhibition" title="Bite inhibition">bite inhibition</a>, from their wolf ancestors, which would have been <a href="/wiki/Pack_hunter" title="Pack hunter">pack hunters</a> with complex <a href="/wiki/Body_language_of_dogs" title="Body language of dogs">body language</a>. These sophisticated forms of social cognition and communication may account for dogs' trainability, playfulness, and ability to fit into human households and social situations,<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and probably also their co-existence with early human hunter-gatherers.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs perform many roles for people, such as <a href="/wiki/Hunting_dog" title="Hunting dog">hunting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herding_dog" title="Herding dog">herding</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sled_dog" title="Sled dog">pulling loads</a>, <a href="/wiki/Guard_dog" title="Guard dog">protection</a>, <a href="/wiki/Police_dog" title="Police dog">assisting police</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Dogs_in_warfare" title="Dogs in warfare">military</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pet" title="Pet">companionship</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Assistance_dog" title="Assistance dog">aiding disabled individuals</a>. These roles in human society have earned them the nickname "<a href="/wiki/Man%27s_best_friend" title="Man's best friend">man's best friend</a>" in the <a href="/wiki/Western_world" title="Western world">Western world</a>. In some cultures, however, dogs <a href="#Dogs_as_food">are also a source of meat</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Wingfield-Hayes_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wingfield-Hayes-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vietnam's_dog_meat_tradition_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vietnam's_dog_meat_tradition-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Pets">Pets</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Siberian_Husky_pho.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Siberian_Husky_pho.jpg/250px-Siberian_Husky_pho.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="237" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Siberian_Husky_pho.jpg/500px-Siberian_Husky_pho.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="711"></a><figcaption>A <a href="/wiki/Siberian_husky" class="mw-redirect" title="Siberian husky">Siberian husky</a> with a human companion</figcaption></figure>
<p>The keeping of dogs as companions, particularly by elites, has a long history.<sup id="cite_ref-Derr_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Derr-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Pet-dog populations grew significantly after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> as <a href="/wiki/Suburbanization" title="Suburbanization">suburbanization</a> increased.<sup id="cite_ref-Derr_196-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Derr-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the 1980s, there have been changes in the pet dog's functions, such as the increased role of dogs in the <a href="/wiki/Emotional_support_animal" title="Emotional support animal">emotional support</a> of their human guardians.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Power_199-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Power-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Within the second half of the 20th century, more and more dog owners considered their animal to be a part of the family. This major social status shift allowed the dog to conform to social expectations of personality and behavior.<sup id="cite_ref-Power_199-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Power-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The second has been the broadening of the concepts of family and the home to include dogs-as-dogs within everyday routines and practices.<sup id="cite_ref-Power_199-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Power-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Products such as dog-training books, classes, and television programs target dog owners.<sup id="cite_ref-Nast_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nast-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Myths_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Myths-201"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some dog-trainers have promoted a <a href="/wiki/Dominance_(ethology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dominance (ethology)">dominance model</a> of dog-human relationships. However, the idea of the <a href="/wiki/Pack_(canine)#Use_in_dog_training" title="Pack (canine)">"alpha dog"</a> trying to be dominant is based on a controversial theory about wolf packs.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It has been disputed that "trying to achieve status" is characteristic of dog-human interactions.<sup id="cite_ref-Bradshaw_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bradshaw-204"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Human family members have increased participation in activities in which the dog is an integral partner, such as <a href="/wiki/Musical_canine_freestyle" title="Musical canine freestyle">dog dancing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Doga_(Dog_Yoga)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doga (Dog Yoga)">dog yoga</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Nast_200-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nast-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>According to statistics published by the American Pet Products Manufacturers Association in the National Pet Owner Survey in 20092010, an estimated 77.5 million people in the United States have pet dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The source shows that nearly 40% of American households own at least one dog, of which 67% own just one dog, 25% own two dogs, and nearly 9% own more than two dogs. The data also shows an equal number of male and female pet dogs; less than one-fifth of the owned dogs come from <a href="/wiki/Animal_shelter" title="Animal shelter">shelters</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-HSO_206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HSO-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Workers">Workers</h3></div>
<p>In addition to dogs' role as companion animals, dogs have been bred for <a href="/wiki/Herding_dog" title="Herding dog">herding livestock</a> (such as <a href="/wiki/Collie" title="Collie">collies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sheepdog" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheepdog">sheepdogs</a>); for hunting; for <a href="/wiki/Pest_control" title="Pest control">rodent control</a> (such as terriers); as <a href="/wiki/Search_and_rescue_dog" title="Search and rescue dog">search and rescue dogs</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> as <a href="/wiki/Detection_dog" title="Detection dog">detection dogs</a> (such as those trained to detect <a href="/wiki/Illegal_drug_trade" title="Illegal drug trade">illicit drugs</a> or <a href="/wiki/Chemical_weapon" title="Chemical weapon">chemical weapons</a>);<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> as homeguard dogs; as <a href="/wiki/Police_dog" title="Police dog">police dogs</a> (sometimes nicknamed "K-9"); as <a href="/wiki/Service_dogs" class="mw-redirect" title="Service dogs">welfare-purpose dogs</a>; as dogs who assist fishermen retrieve their nets; and as dogs that pull loads (such as <a href="/wiki/Sled_dog" title="Sled dog">sled dogs</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-ADW_83-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ADW-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 1957, the dog <a href="/wiki/Laika" title="Laika">Laika</a> became one of the first animals to be launched into <a href="/wiki/Geocentric_orbit" title="Geocentric orbit">Earth orbit</a> aboard the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviets</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_2" title="Sputnik 2">Sputnik 2</a></i>; Laika died during the flight from <a href="/wiki/Hyperthermia" title="Hyperthermia">overheating</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Various kinds of service dogs and assistance dogs, including <a href="/wiki/Guide_dog" title="Guide dog">guide dogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hearing_dog" title="Hearing dog">hearing dogs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mobility_assistance_dog" title="Mobility assistance dog">mobility assistance dogs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Psychiatric_service_dog" class="mw-redirect" title="Psychiatric service dog">psychiatric service dogs</a>, assist individuals with disabilities.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A study of 29 dogs found that 9 dogs owned by people with epilepsy were reported to exhibit attention-getting behavior to their handler 30 seconds to 45 minutes prior to an impending seizure; there was no significant correlation between the patients' demographics, health, or attitude towards their pets.<sup id="cite_ref-seizure_215-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-seizure-215"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Shows_and_sports">Shows and sports</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Dog_show" title="Dog show">Dog show</a></div>
<p>Dogs compete in breed-conformation shows and <a href="/wiki/List_of_dog_sports" title="List of dog sports">dog sports</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Racing" title="Racing">racing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sledding" title="Sledding">sledding</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dog_agility" title="Dog agility">agility competitions</a>). In dog shows, also referred to as "breed shows", a judge familiar with the specific dog breed evaluates individual purebred dogs for conformity with their established breed type as described in a <a href="/wiki/Breed_standard" title="Breed standard">breed standard</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Weight_pulling" title="Weight pulling">Weight pulling</a>, a dog sport involving pulling weight, has been criticized for promoting <a href="/wiki/Doping_in_sport" title="Doping in sport">doping</a> and for its risk of injury.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Dogs_as_food">Dogs as food</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dog_meat" title="Dog meat">Dog meat</a></div>
<p>Humans have consumed dog meat going back at least 14,000 years. It is unknown to what extent prehistoric dogs were consumed and bred for meat. For centuries, the practice was prevalent in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Asia" title="East Asia">East Asia</a>, Africa, and <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a> before cultural changes triggered by the spread of religions resulted in dog meat consumption declining and becoming more taboo.<sup id="cite_ref-Simoons-1994_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Simoons-1994-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Polynesia" title="Polynesia">Polynesia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_Mexico" title="Pre-Columbian Mexico">pre-Columbian Mexico</a> historically consumed dog meat.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some <a href="/wiki/Native_American_dogs" title="Native American dogs">Native American dogs</a>, like the <a href="/wiki/Peruvian_Hairless_Dog" title="Peruvian Hairless Dog">Peruvian Hairless Dog</a> and <a href="/wiki/Xoloitzcuintle" title="Xoloitzcuintle">Xoloitzcuintle</a>, were raised to be sacrificed and eaten.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Han_Chinese" title="Han Chinese">Han Chinese</a> traditionally ate dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-Wangyun-2018_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wangyun-2018-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Consumption of dog meat declined but did not end during the <a href="/wiki/Sui_dynasty" title="Sui dynasty">Sui dynasty</a> (581618) and <a href="/wiki/Tang_dynasty" title="Tang dynasty">Tang dynasty</a> (618907) due in part to the spread of Buddhism and the upper class rejecting the practice.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dog consumption was rare in India, Iran, and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Simoons-1994_218-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Simoons-1994-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Eating dog meat is a <a href="/wiki/Taboo" title="Taboo">social taboo</a> in most parts of the world,<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> though some still consume it in <a href="/wiki/Modern_era" title="Modern era">modern times</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It is still consumed in some <a href="/wiki/East_Asian" class="mw-redirect" title="East Asian">East Asian</a> countries, including <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Wingfield-Hayes_194-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wingfield-Hayes-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Vietnam's_dog_meat_tradition_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vietnam's_dog_meat_tradition-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> An estimated 30 million dogs are killed and consumed in Asia every year.<sup id="cite_ref-Wangyun-2018_224-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Wangyun-2018-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> China is the world's largest consumer of dogs, with an estimated 10 to 20 million dogs killed every year for human consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In Vietnam, about 5 million dogs are slaughtered annually.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2024, China, Singapore, and Thailand placed a ban on the consumption of dogs within their borders.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In some parts of <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a><sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Central_Asia" title="Central Asia">Central Asia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-:2_238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-238"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> dog fat is reportedly believed to be beneficial for the lungs.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Proponents of eating dog meat have argued that placing a distinction between livestock and dogs is Western hypocrisy and that there is no difference in eating different animals' meat.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>There is a long history of <a href="/wiki/Dog_meat_consumption_in_South_Korea" title="Dog meat consumption in South Korea">dog meat consumption in South Korea</a>, but the practice has fallen out of favor.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A 2017 survey found that under 40% of participants supported a ban on the distribution and consumption of dog meat. This increased to over 50% in 2020, suggesting changing attitudes, particularly among younger individuals.<sup id="cite_ref-:7_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:7-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_South_Korea" title="Government of South Korea">South Korean government</a> passed a bill banning restaurants that sell dog meat from doing so during that year's <a href="/wiki/2018_Winter_Olympics" title="2018 Winter Olympics">Winter Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On 9 January 2024, the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(South_Korea)" title="National Assembly (South Korea)">South Korean parliament</a> passed a law banning the distribution and sale of dog meat. It will take effect in 2027, with plans to assist dog farmers in transitioning to other products.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The primary type of dog raised for meat in South Korea has been the <a href="/wiki/Nureongi" title="Nureongi">Nureongi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a> where meat is scarce, eating dog is a common and accepted practice, officially promoted by the government.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Health_risks">Health risks</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Dog_bite" title="Dog bite">Dog bite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canine_vector-borne_disease" title="Canine vector-borne disease">Canine vector-borne disease</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dog_bite_prevention" class="mw-redirect" title="Dog bite prevention">Dog bite prevention</a></div>
<p>In 2018, the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO) reported that 59,000 people died globally from <a href="/wiki/Rabies" title="Rabies">rabies</a>, with 59.6% of the deaths in Asia and 36.4% in Africa. Rabies is a disease for which dogs are the most significant <a href="/wiki/Disease_vector" title="Disease vector">vector</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dog bites affect tens of millions of people globally each year.<sup id="cite_ref-:6_252-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The primary victims of dog bite incidents are children. They are more likely to sustain more serious injuries from bites, which can lead to death.<sup id="cite_ref-:6_252-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:6-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Sharp claws can lacerate flesh and cause serious infections.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dogs_in_the_United_States" title="Dogs in the United States">In the United States</a>, cats and dogs are a factor in more than 86,000 falls each year.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It has been estimated that around 2% of dog-related injuries treated in U.K. hospitals are domestic accidents. The same study concluded that dog-associated <a href="/wiki/Traffic_collision" title="Traffic collision">road accidents</a> involving injuries more commonly involve <a href="/wiki/Two-wheeler" title="Two-wheeler">two-wheeled vehicles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Some countries and cities have also banned or restricted certain dog breeds, usually for safety concerns.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Toxocara_canis" title="Toxocara canis">Toxocara canis</a></i> (dog <a href="/wiki/Roundworm" class="mw-redirect" title="Roundworm">roundworm</a>) eggs in dog feces can cause <a href="/wiki/Toxocariasis" title="Toxocariasis">toxocariasis</a>. It is estimated that nearly 14% of people in the United States are infected with <i>Toxocara</i>; about 10,000 cases are reported each year.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Untreated toxocariasis can cause retinal damage and decreased vision.<sup id="cite_ref-kidshealth_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kidshealth-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dog feces can also contain <a href="/wiki/Hookworm" title="Hookworm">hookworms</a> that cause <a href="/wiki/Cutaneous_larva_migrans" title="Cutaneous larva migrans">cutaneous larva migrans</a> in humans.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Health_benefits">Health benefits</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Walking_the_dog_(1945527533).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Walking_the_dog_%281945527533%29.jpg/250px-Walking_the_dog_%281945527533%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="375" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Walking_the_dog_%281945527533%29.jpg/500px-Walking_the_dog_%281945527533%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="3888"></a><figcaption>A woman walking a dog</figcaption></figure>
<p>The scientific evidence is mixed as to whether a dog's companionship can enhance human physical and psychological well-being.<sup id="cite_ref-Pet_ownership_and_human_health:_a_brief_review_of_evidence_and_issues_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pet_ownership_and_human_health:_a_brief_review_of_evidence_and_issues-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Studies suggest that there are benefits to physical health and psychological well-being, but they have been criticized for being "poorly controlled".<sup id="cite_ref-Health_effects_of_ownership_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Health_effects_of_ownership-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> One study states that "the health of elderly people is related to their health habits and <a href="/wiki/Social_support" title="Social support">social supports</a> but not to their ownership of, or attachment to, a companion animal".<sup id="cite_ref-:4_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Earlier studies have shown that pet-dog or -cat guardians make fewer hospital visits and are less likely to be on medication for heart problems and sleeping difficulties than non-guardians.<sup id="cite_ref-:4_264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:4-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> People with pet dogs took considerably more physical exercise than those with cats or those without pets; these effects are relatively long-term.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated717_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated717-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Pet guardianship has also been associated with increased survival in cases of <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_disease" title="Coronary artery disease">coronary artery disease</a>. Human guardians are significantly less likely to die within one year of an acute <a href="/wiki/Myocardial_infarction" title="Myocardial infarction">myocardial infarction</a> than those who do not own dogs.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Studies have found a small to moderate correlation between dog-ownership and increased adult physical-activity levels.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>
A 2005 paper by the <i><a href="/wiki/British_Medical_Journal" class="mw-redirect" title="British Medical Journal">British Medical Journal</a></i> states:<sup id="cite_ref-Pet_ownership_and_human_health:_a_brief_review_of_evidence_and_issues_261-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pet_ownership_and_human_health:_a_brief_review_of_evidence_and_issues-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><blockquote><p> Recent research has failed to support earlier findings that pet ownership is associated with a reduced risk of <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular disease</a>, a reduced use of <a href="/wiki/General_practitioner" title="General practitioner">general practitioner</a> services, or any psychological or physical benefits on health for community dwelling older people. Research has, however, pointed to significantly less <a href="/wiki/Absenteeism" title="Absenteeism">absenteeism</a> from school through sickness among children who live with pets.</p></blockquote><p> Health benefits of dogs can result from contact with dogs in general, not solely from having dogs as pets. For example, when in a pet dog's presence, people show reductions in cardiovascular, behavioral, and psychological indicators of anxiety<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and are exposed to <a href="/wiki/Probiotic" title="Probiotic">immune-stimulating microorganisms</a>, which can protect against allergies and autoimmune diseases (according to the <a href="/wiki/Hygiene_hypothesis" title="Hygiene hypothesis">hygiene hypothesis</a>). Other benefits include dogs as social support.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>One study indicated that wheelchair-users experience more positive social interactions with strangers when accompanied by a dog than when they are not.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In a 2015 study, it was found that having a pet made people more inclined to foster positive relationships with their neighbors.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In one study, new guardians reported a significant reduction in minor health problems during the first month following pet acquisition, which was sustained through the 10-month study.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated717_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated717-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Using dogs and other animals as a part of therapy dates back to the late-18th century, when animals were introduced into mental institutions to help socialize patients with <a href="/wiki/Mental_disorder" title="Mental disorder">mental disorders</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Animal-assisted intervention research has shown that animal-assisted therapy with a dog can increase smiling and laughing among people with <a href="/wiki/Alzheimer%27s_disease" title="Alzheimer's disease">Alzheimer's disease</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> One study demonstrated that children with ADHD and <a href="/wiki/Conduct_disorder" title="Conduct disorder">conduct disorders</a> who participated in an education program with dogs and other animals showed increased attendance, knowledge, and skill-objectives and decreased <a href="/wiki/Anti-social_behaviour" title="Anti-social behaviour">antisocial</a> and <a href="/wiki/Violence" title="Violence">violent behavior</a> compared with those not in an animal-assisted program.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cultural_importance">Cultural importance</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cultural_depictions_of_dogs" title="Cultural depictions of dogs">Cultural depictions of dogs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dogs_in_religion" title="Dogs in religion">Dogs in religion</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_fictional_dogs" title="List of fictional dogs">List of fictional dogs</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Cerberus-Blake.jpeg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Cerberus-Blake.jpeg/250px-Cerberus-Blake.jpeg" decoding="async" width="250" height="177" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Cerberus-Blake.jpeg/500px-Cerberus-Blake.jpeg 1.5x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="725"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Cerberus" title="Cerberus">Cerberus</a> with the gluttons in <a href="/wiki/Dante" class="mw-redirect" title="Dante">Dante</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Third_Circle_of_Hell" class="mw-redirect" title="Third Circle of Hell">Third Circle of Hell</a>, depicted by <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Artworks have depicted dogs as symbols of <a href="/wiki/Guide" title="Guide">guidance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Protection" title="Protection">protection</a>, <a href="/wiki/Loyalty" title="Loyalty">loyalty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fidelity" title="Fidelity">fidelity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Faithfulness" title="Faithfulness">faithfulness</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alertness" title="Alertness">alertness</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Love" title="Love">love</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In ancient <a href="/wiki/Mesopotamia" title="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>, from the <a href="/wiki/Babylonia" title="Babylonia">Old Babylonian period</a> until the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Babylonian_Empire" title="Neo-Babylonian Empire">Neo-Babylonian period</a>, dogs were the symbol of <a href="/wiki/Ninisina" title="Ninisina">Ninisina</a>, the goddess of healing and medicine,<sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and her worshippers frequently dedicated small models of seated dogs to her.<sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_276-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire" title="Neo-Assyrian Empire">Neo-Assyrian</a> and Neo-Babylonian periods, dogs served as emblems of magical protection.<sup id="cite_ref-BlackGreen1992_276-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BlackGreen1992-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Korea" title="Korea">Korea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a>, dogs are viewed as kind protectors.<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In mythology, dogs often appear as pets or as watchdogs.<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Stories of dogs guarding the gates of the underworld recur throughout Indo-European mythologies<sup id="cite_ref-MalloryAdams2006_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MalloryAdams2006-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-West2007_279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-West2007-279"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and may originate from <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_mythology" title="Proto-Indo-European mythology">Proto-Indo-European traditions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-MalloryAdams2006_278-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MalloryAdams2006-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-West2007_279-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-West2007-279"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Greek_mythology" title="Greek mythology">Greek mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cerberus" title="Cerberus">Cerberus</a> is a three-headed, <a href="/wiki/Dragon" title="Dragon">dragon</a>-tailed watchdog who guards the gates of <a href="/wiki/Hades" title="Hades">Hades</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Dogs also feature in association with the Greek goddess <a href="/wiki/Hecate" title="Hecate">Hecate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Norse_mythology" title="Norse mythology">Norse mythology</a>, a dog called <a href="/wiki/Garmr" title="Garmr">Garmr</a> guards <a href="/wiki/Hel_(location)" title="Hel (location)">Hel</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Death_in_Norse_paganism#Afterlives_and_rebirth" title="Death in Norse paganism">realm of the dead</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Persian_mythology" title="Persian mythology">Persian mythology</a>, two four-eyed dogs guard the <a href="/wiki/Chinvat_Bridge" title="Chinvat Bridge">Chinvat Bridge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Welsh_mythology" title="Welsh mythology">Welsh mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/C%C5%B5n_Annwn" title="Cn Annwn">Cn Annwn</a> guards <a href="/wiki/Annwn" title="Annwn">Annwn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Hindu_mythology" title="Hindu mythology">Hindu mythology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yama" title="Yama">Yama</a>, the god of death, owns two watchdogs named <a href="/wiki/Sharvara_and_Shyama" title="Sharvara and Shyama">Shyama and Sharvara</a>, which each have four eyesthey are said to watch over the gates of <a href="/wiki/Naraka" title="Naraka">Naraka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A black dog is considered to be the <i><a href="/wiki/Vahana" title="Vahana">vahana</a></i> (vehicle) of <a href="/wiki/Bhairava" title="Bhairava">Bhairava</a> (an incarnation of Shiva).<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, dogs represent faithfulness.<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Within the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> denomination specifically, the iconography of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Dominic" title="Saint Dominic">Saint Dominic</a> includes a dog after the saint's mother dreamt of a dog springing from her womb and became pregnant shortly after that.<sup id="cite_ref-CP2017_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CP2017-283"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As such, the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Order" title="Dominican Order">Dominican Order</a> (<a href="/wiki/Ecclesiastical_Latin" title="Ecclesiastical Latin">Ecclesiastical Latin</a>: <i>Domini canis</i>) means "dog of the Lord" or "hound of the Lord".<sup id="cite_ref-CP2017_283-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CP2017-283"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In Christian folklore, a <a href="/wiki/Church_grim" title="Church grim">church grim</a> often takes the form of a black dog to guard Christian churches and their <a href="/wiki/Churchyard" title="Churchyard">churchyards</a> from <a href="/wiki/Sacrilege" title="Sacrilege">sacrilege</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Dyer1898_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dyer1898-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jewish_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish law">Jewish law</a> does not prohibit keeping dogs and other pets but requires Jews to feed dogs (and other animals that they own) before themselves and to make arrangements for feeding them before obtaining them.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The view on dogs in <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> is <a href="/wiki/Animals_in_Islam" title="Animals in Islam">mixed</a>, with some schools of thought viewing them as unclean,<sup id="cite_ref-Sherman2008_277-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sherman2008-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> although <a href="/wiki/Khaled_Abou_El_Fadl" title="Khaled Abou El Fadl">Khaled Abou El Fadl</a> states that this view is based on "pre-Islamic Arab mythology" and "a tradition [...] falsely attributed to the Prophet".<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Sunni <a href="/wiki/Maliki_school" title="Maliki school">Maliki school</a> jurists disagree with the idea that dogs are unclean.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Terminology">Terminology</h2></div>
<ul><li><i>Dog</i>  the species (or subspecies) as a whole, also any male member of the same.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarperCollins2021[httpswwwcollinsdictionarycomdictionaryenglishdog_"dog"]_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarperCollins2021[httpswwwcollinsdictionarycomdictionaryenglishdog_"dog"]-289"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><i>Bitch</i>  any female member of the species (or subspecies).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarperCollins2021[httpswwwcollinsdictionarycomdictionaryenglishbitch_"bitch"]_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarperCollins2021[httpswwwcollinsdictionarycomdictionaryenglishbitch_"bitch"]-290"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Puppy" title="Puppy">Puppy</a></i> or <i>pup</i>  a young member of the species (or subspecies) under 12 months old.<sup id="cite_ref-Alderton_291-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alderton-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><i>Sire</i>  the male parent of a litter.<sup id="cite_ref-Alderton_291-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alderton-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><i>Dam</i>  the female parent of a litter.<sup id="cite_ref-Alderton_291-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alderton-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><i><a href="/wiki/Litter_(animal)" class="mw-redirect" title="Litter (animal)">Litter</a></i>  all of the puppies resulting from a single whelping.<sup id="cite_ref-Alderton_291-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alderton-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><i>Whelping</i>  the act of a bitch giving birth.<sup id="cite_ref-Alderton_291-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alderton-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><i>Whelps</i>  puppies still dependent upon their dam.<sup id="cite_ref-Alderton_291-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alderton-291"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul>

The dog (Canis familiaris or Canis lupus familiaris) is a domesticated descendant of the gray wolf. Also called the domestic dog, it was selectively bred from a population of wolves during the Late Pleistocene by hunter-gatherers. The dog was the first species to be domesticated by humans, over 14,000 years ago and before the development of agriculture. Due to their long association with humans, dogs have gained the ability to thrive on a starch-rich diet that would be inadequate for other canids.

Dogs have been bred for desired behaviors, sensory capabilities, and physical attributes. Dog breeds vary widely in shape, size, and color. They have the same number of bones (with the exception of the tail), powerful jaws that house around 42 teeth, and well-developed senses of smell, hearing, and sight. Compared to humans, dogs possess a superior sense of smell and hearing, but inferior visual acuity. Dogs perform many roles for humans, such as hunting, herding, pulling loads, protection, companionship, therapy, aiding disabled people, and assisting police and the military.

Communication in dogs includes eye gaze, facial expression, vocalization, body posture (including movements of bodies and limbs), and gustatory communication (scents, pheromones, and taste). They mark their territories by urinating on them, which is more likely when entering a new environment. Over the millennia, dogs have uniquely adapted to human behavior; this adaptation includes being able to understand and communicate with humans. As such, the humancanine bond has been a topic of frequent study, and dogs' influence on human society has given them the sobriquet of "man's best friend".

The global dog population is estimated at 700million to 1billion, distributed around the world. The dog is the most popular pet in the United States, present in 3440% of households. Developed countries make up approximately 20% of the global dog population, while around 75% of dogs are estimated to be from developing countries, mainly in the form of feral and community dogs.

Taxonomy
